<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367868995"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>INTRODUCTION</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. is organized under the laws of British Columbia, Canada. &nbsp;In this Annual Report, the &#147;Company&#148;, &#147;Barrier&#148;, &#147;we&#148;, &#147;our&#148; and &#147;us&#148; refer to International Barrier Technology Inc. and its subsidiaries (unless the context otherwise requires). &nbsp;We refer you to the actual corporate documents for more complete information than may be contained in this Annual Report. &nbsp;Our principal corporate offices are located at 510 4th Street North, Watkins, Minnesota, USA 55389. &nbsp;Our telephone number is 320-764-5797.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>BUSINESS OF INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. develops, manufactures, and markets proprietary fire resistant building materials designed to help protect people and property from the destruction of fire. &nbsp;The Company uses a patented, non-combustible, non-toxic <I>Pyrotite&#174;</I> formulation that is used to coat wood panels and has potential application to engineered wood products, paint, plastics, and expanded polystyrene. &nbsp;Sales have been US$8.2.0 million and US$6.0 million during Fiscal 2014 and 2013, respectively.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>In this Annual Report, unless otherwise specified, all dollar amounts are expressed in U.S. Dollars (&#147;$&#148;).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<A NAME="_Toc367868996"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-size:12pt" align=center><B>PART I</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B>ITEM 1. &nbsp;BUSINESS</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>1.A. &nbsp;General Development of Business</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><U>Introduction</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. and its subsidiaries are collectively hereinafter referred to as the &#147;Company&#148;.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Incorporated in July 1986, pursuant to agreements, the Company acquired the rights to the Pyrotite&#174; Technology for Canada in July 1986 and for the United States in March 1992. &nbsp;The Canadian rights and the US rights under the 1992 agreement were voluntarily terminated in January 1996 due to marketing conflict with a corporation which acquired the licensor&#146;s rights to the technology. &nbsp;A new agreement for the rights in the United States was signed in January 1996 and revised in March 1996. &nbsp;The Company acquired the world-wide rights to the Pyrotite&#174; technology, including: US patents; foreign patent filings; manufacturing know-how; trade secrets, and trademarks pursuant to a March 2004 agreement. &nbsp;The Company completed construction of a new manufacturing facility in Minnesota, USA in December 1995; the facility was upgraded to include substantial automation, increased capacity and product quality in April/May 2000; as Barrier continued to achieve double digit growth year after year, it decided the current manufacturing facility needed to be expanded. &nbsp;The planning and development of a higher volume and more fully automated facility began in 2004; the first phase that included the building addition was complete in March 2005. &nbsp;The second phase of the new line development was complete in August 2005 and the first commercial production run was in March 2006. &nbsp;The final phase of equipment installation, shake down improvements, and training was complete in late 2006 at which time full commercial production began.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company has been involved in the development and manufacturing/marketing of fire-rated building products since 1986, including current products: Pyrotite&#174;, a fire-barrier material comprised of the patented formulation reinforced with chopped fiberglass strands and applied adhered directly to structural sheathing (OSB &#150; oriented strand board or plywood) designed to prevent ignition and inhibit the spread of flames. &nbsp;The products are currently marketed through exclusive supply agreements as LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing into Residential Roof Deck, Wall Assembly, Wildland Urban Interface Zones, and Structurally Insulated Panel market; and MuleHide FR Deck Panel into the Commercial Modular Market. &nbsp;In early 2013, LP and Barrier extended their existing Supply Agreement through December 31, 2013, with an option to extend through December 31, 2014 with mutual agreement. LP is the largest producer of Oriented Strand Board (OSB) in the world and believes that Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; Technology will help them achieve their strategy of providing a number of value added OSB products to the building community. &nbsp;The agreement gives LP the exclusive right to sell Pyrotite&#174; treated panel products in North America, in all markets other than Commercial Modular (MuleHide Products, Inc.), under their brand name LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing. &nbsp;During the 2014 fiscal year, the Company granted a license for the manufacture and distribution of Pyrotite&#174; products in a plant in the European Union and Russia. &nbsp;The agreement contemplates the Licensee developing additional production facilities over the term of the license. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>1.B. &nbsp;Financial Information About Segments</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Refer to the audited financial statements for Fiscal 2014 ended June 30th (footnote #11 &#147;Segmented Information and Sales Concentration&#148;) for this information.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>1.C. &nbsp;Narrative Description of Business</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. (Barrier) manufactures and sells fire-rated building materials in the United States. &nbsp;Barrier has a patented fire protective material (Pyrotite&#174;) that is applied to building materials to greatly improve their respective fire resistant properties. Coated wood panel products are sold to builders through building product distribution companies all over the United States. &nbsp;Many of the top multifamily homebuilders in the US utilize Barrier&#146;s fire-rated structural panel manufactured with Pyrotite&#174; in areas where the building code requires the use of a fire-rated building panel.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier sells LP&#174; FlameBlock Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing to LP&#174; Building Products and sales to LP accounted for 72% of Fiscal 2014 revenues. &nbsp;Barrier sells MuleHide FR Deck Panel to MuleHide Products, Inc. and sales to MuleHide accounted for 28% of Fiscal 2014 revenues. &nbsp;Barrier sells LP&#174; FlameBlock Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing to LP&#174; Building Products and sales to LP accounted for 70% of Fiscal 2013 revenues. &nbsp;Barrier sells MuleHide FR Deck Panel to MuleHide Products, Inc. and sales to MuleHide accounted for 30% of Fiscal 2013 revenues.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s business is based on the premise that building projects occasionally require fire resistive performance. &nbsp;Whether based on a requirement of a national or local building code, the possibility for lower insurance rates, or simply the desire for safety by a building owner, Barrier&#146;s health as a manufacturing company is based on a demand for resistive building products. &nbsp;Any factor that could mitigate the demand for fire resistive construction could have a negative impact on Barrier.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>5</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Barrier suffers a larger risk in the possibility that a new generation of technology that will impart fire resistance to building products may be developed. &nbsp;New technology may serve to decrease the demand for Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; products if the new technology proved to impart either better characteristics of fire performance or was found to be less expensive to produce and market than Blazeguard. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s management team makes a concerted effort to stay abreast of new technologies as they are being developed. &nbsp;Barrier does this by staying in close contact with the industry via trade associations (e.g. The National Association of Home Builders, NAHB) and the independent research laboratories that are asked to test these new technologies and products as they are developed. &nbsp;However, there is no guarantee that the Company is able to adopt and utilize the new technology. &nbsp;New technologies require years of testing, not only in development but in use, before they are accepted and &#147;evaluated for use&#148; by the major building code agencies such as The International Code Council (ICC).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s business is directly related to housing/building starts in the United States. &nbsp;Any factor resulting in a slowdown of economic activity, especially those that result in an increase in interest rates will have a negative impact on Barrier&#146;s business. &nbsp;New housing starts in the U.S. continue to be on the rise. &nbsp;The U.S. Census Bureau reported 1,093,000 new housing starts in July 2014 (adjusted on an annual basis). July's numbers were 15.7 percent higher than the June 2014 estimate of 945,000 and 21.7 percent higher than the July 2013 annually adjusted rate of 898,000. &nbsp;There continues to be a risk that the economy is not yet stable enough to support long term improvements in new housing starts. &nbsp;If housing growth becomes unstable, sales of Pyrotite&#174; products could be negatively impacted or unpredictable.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier presumes that corporate growth will be funded from positive cash flow, conventional bank loans, and from the occasional sale of equity to generate needed capital. &nbsp;The business plan, however, anticipates a few years of very rapid sales volume increases. &nbsp;Companies experiencing rapid growth depend upon solid support both in the market place and in the manufacturing facilities themselves. &nbsp;Ensuring that capital is available to increase production capacity and to provide support materials and training in the market place is essential to success.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier is relatively &#147;thin&#148; in its management team. &nbsp;&nbsp;Barrier has intentionally kept the number of middle and upper management at a minimum in an effort to conserve financial resources. &nbsp;As the company grows it will be essential to have new talent emerging to help provide leadership in the factories of production and in the market place to introduce the products to new markets: &nbsp;both in geography and in use. &nbsp;As long as the management team is thin, the impact of losing a key player is very large.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier relies on key relationships with industry leaders to maintain its position in the market place. &nbsp;Barrier is dependent upon suppliers to provide key elements of production at critical times at reasonable prices. &nbsp;While the majority of these materials are readily available and abundant, without quality suppliers providing reasonable terms of sales, Barrier would not be able to stay in business: there would be no operating or working goods of production to use in the manufacturing process.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>R&amp;D activity continues to focus on developing and improving the designs of existing 1 and 2-hr certified interior and exterior wall assemblies. New R&amp;D projects were launched during the current fiscal year to examine the development of fire-rated engineered wood products (EWP), including I-joist and Rimboard. &nbsp;With the expanded use of EWP in building applications, as an alternative to solid sawn lumber, the importance of evaluating their performance during a fire has escalated tremendously. &nbsp;Efforts to develop fire-rated EWP is at an early stage, however, largely because building code requirements and the acceptance criteria for evaluating performance and suitability are still being developed. &nbsp;Barrier feels there is great opportunity here, and will continue to pursue techniques to fire treat EWP with our Pyrotite&#174; Technology as the year progresses. During the year ended June 30, 2014, the Company incurred research and development costs of $27,740 (2013: $30,137).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Seasonality</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The building products industry in the United States does experience seasonality with housing starts generally depressed in winter months. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; products, however, are sold in housing markets that have excellent winter business, including the states of Georgia, Texas, Florida and California. &nbsp;Also, much of the modular housing, including the foam core panel market, performs a considerable amount of their required construction inside factories. Since the work is done within protected environments they tend to be less impacted by the winter season than typical building projects. &nbsp;Seasonality, therefore, is not considered to be a major impediment to Barrier&#146;s success in the US market place.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Dependency upon Patents/Licenses/Processes</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Pursuant to an agreement for sale of technology dated 3/1/2004 (&#147;original agreement&#148;), between the Company and Pyrotite Corporation, the Company acquired the rights (previously licensed) to certain fire retardant technology and trademarks for $1,000,000. &nbsp;These rights and technology included all of the patents that deal with &#147;surface applied&#148; and &#147;integral&#148; OSB technology Pyrotite&#174; technology. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>6</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier utilizes patented manufacturing technology, as well as manufacturing know-how and trade secrets that have been developed and are closely protected by Barrier.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The manufacturing process for the Pyrotite&#174; products is protected by trade secrets and has a patent on an improved technology. &nbsp;International Barrier Technology, Inc. and Barrier Technology Corporation are, in that regard, totally dependent upon these for success in the business.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>All employees are required to sign a Confidentiality Agreement that incorporates a &#147;do not compete clause&#148;. &nbsp;As these clauses pertain to Barrier&#146;s employees at the US operations, they have been drafted to conform to the strictest interpretation under Minnesota law.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Employees</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>As of 8/15/2014, the Company had 28 full-time employees, 2 full time Executive Officers and 1 part-time Executive Officer. &nbsp;As of 6/30/2014, the Company had 27 full-time employees, and 2 full-time Executive Officers and 1 part-time Executive Officer. &nbsp;As of 6/30/2013, the Company had 25 full-time employees, two full-time Executive Officers and one part-time Executive Officer.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Dependency upon Customers</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><U>Fiscal 2014</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>During Fiscal 2014, the company&#146;s largest customer was LP&#174; Building Products (LP). &nbsp;LP is a customer that services the multifamily residential roof deck construction, wall assemblies, and structural insulated panels (SIPs) markets. &nbsp;LP purchased 72% of the 19,750,792 sq. ft. of Pyrotite&#174; products shipped in Fiscal 2014. &nbsp;LP is the largest producer of Oriented Strand Board (OSB) in the world and believes that Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; Technology will help them achieve their strategy of providing a number of value added OSB products to the building community. &nbsp;Through an exclusive supply agreement, LP has the exclusive right to sell Pyrotite&#174; treated panel products in North America, in all markets other than the commercial modular (MuleHide Products, Inc.) market, under their brand name LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; is sold through wholesale distribution companies such as Boise, Cedar Creek, Curtis Lumber, ProBuild, Reliable Wholesale, Taiga Building Products, Vandermeer Forest Products, Universal Forest Products, and Weekes Forest Products. &nbsp;The MidAtlantic Region market (MD-VA) was the strongest region in these markets with 53% of total sales into these markets. &nbsp;Other regions in these markets include the South, the Midwest, the West and Canada). &nbsp;The building products distribution companies mentioned have a presence in all of these areas and are consistent FlameBlock customers throughout these geographies.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The second largest market for Pyrotite&#174; products was the commercial modular market. &nbsp;MuleHide Products, Inc. &#147;Mulehide&#148;. &nbsp;Mulehide is the company that services the commercial modular market including selling Pyrotite&#174; products to the commercial modular market. &nbsp;Commercial modular sales accounted for 28% of total shipments in 2014. &nbsp;Product shipped to MuleHide Products is through an exclusive supply agreement and private labeled MuleHide FR Deck Panel. &nbsp;The FR Deck Panel is distributed through ABC Supply Company locations throughout the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><U>Fiscal 2013</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>During Fiscal 2013, the company&#146;s largest customer was LP&#174; Building Products (LP). &nbsp;LP is a customer that services the multifamily residential roof deck construction, wall assemblies, and structural insulated panels (SIPs) markets. &nbsp;LP purchased 70% of the 13,243,741 sq. ft. of Pyrotite&#174; products shipped in Fiscal 2013. &nbsp;LP is the largest producer of Oriented Strand Board (OSB) in the world and believes that Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; Technology will help them achieve their strategy of providing a number of value added OSB products to the building community. &nbsp;Through an exclusive supply agreement, LP has the exclusive right to sell Pyrotite&#174; treated panel products in North America, in all markets other than the commercial modular (MuleHide Products, Inc.) market, under their brand name LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>LP&#174; FlameBlock&#174; is sold through wholesale distribution companies such as Biewer Lumber, Boise, Builders FirstSource, Cedar Creek, Curtis Lumber, ProBuild, Reliable Wholesale, Taiga Building Products, Vandermeer Forest Products, Universal Forest Products, and Weekes Forest Products. &nbsp;The MidAtlantic Region market (MD-VA) was the strongest region in these markets with 43% of total sales into these markets. &nbsp;Other regions in these markets include the South, the Midwest, the West and Canada). &nbsp;The building products distribution companies mentioned have a presence in all of these areas and are consistent FlameBlock customers throughout these geographies.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>7</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>The second largest market for Pyrotite&#174; products was the commercial modular market. &nbsp;MuleHide Products, Inc. &#147;Mulehide&#148;. &nbsp;Mulehide is the company that services the commercial modular market including selling Pyrotite&#174; products to the commercial modular market. &nbsp;Commercial modular sales accounted for 30% of total shipments in 2013. &nbsp;Product shipped to MuleHide Products is through an exclusive supply agreement and private labeled MuleHide FR Deck Panel. &nbsp;The FR Deck Panel is distributed through ABC Supply Company locations throughout the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>1.D. &nbsp;Financial Information about Geographic Areas</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">During Fiscal 2014 and 2013, all sales were in the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>At 6/30/2014 and 6/30/2013: $4,302,356 and $3,903,819 of the assets were located in the United States and $14,959 and $18,096 were located in Canada, respectively.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367868997"></A><P style="margin:0px"><B><U>ITEM 1A. &nbsp;RISK FACTORS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>In addition to the other information presented in this Annual Report, the following should be considered carefully in evaluating the Company and its business. &nbsp;This Annual Report contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. &nbsp;The Company's actual results may differ materially from results discussed in the forward-looking statements. &nbsp;Factors that might cause such a difference include those discussed below and elsewhere in this Annual Report.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>General Corporate Risks</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Investors may be disadvantaged because the Company is incorporated in Canada, which has different laws.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The articles/by-laws and the laws of Canada are different from those typical in the United States. &nbsp;The typical rights of investors in Canadian companies differ modestly from those in the United States. &nbsp;Such differences may cause investors legal difficulties.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>U.S. investors may not be able to enforce their civil liabilities against the Company or its directors, controlling persons and officers.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>It may be difficult to bring and enforce suits against the Company. &nbsp;The Company is a corporation incorporated under the laws of the British Columbia, Canada. &nbsp;A majority of the Company's directors are resident outside the United States, and all or substantial portions of their assets are located outside of the United States. &nbsp;As a result, it may be difficult for U.S. holders of the Company&#146;s common shares to effect service of process on these persons within the United States or to realize in the United States upon judgments rendered against them. &nbsp;In addition, a shareholder should not assume that the courts of Canada (i) would enforce judgments of U.S. courts obtained in actions against the Company or such persons predicated upon the civil liability provisions of the U.S. federal securities laws or other laws of the United States, or (ii) would enforce, in original actions, liabilities against us or such persons predicated upon the U.S. federal securities laws or other laws of the United States.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Passive Foreign Investment Company (&#147;PFIC&#148;) designation could lead to an adverse tax situation for U.S. investors.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>U.S. investors in the Company could be subject to U.S. taxation at possibly adverse or higher rates and under a system that might be more complicated and unfamiliar to them. &nbsp;For example, a U.S investor might be subject to special tax rules with respect to any &#147;excess distribution&#148; received and any gain realized from a sale or other disposition (including a pledge) of that holder's shares. &nbsp;Distributions a U.S. investor receives in a taxable year that are greater than 125% of the average annual distributions received during the shorter of the three preceding taxable years or the holder's holding period for the shares will be treated as excess distributions. &nbsp;For example, under certain circumstances, a U.S. investor who is an individual might be subject to information reporting requirements and backup withholding, currently at a 28% rate, on dividends received on common shares. &nbsp;If a U.S. Holder holds shares in any year in which the Company is a PFIC, that holder might be required to file Internal Revenue Service Form 8621.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>Risks Relating to Financial Condition</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>The Company has accumulated losses since inception.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Since inception through June 30, 2014, the Company has an accumulated deficit of ($14,203,045). &nbsp;In addition, our operating results in the future may be subject to fluctuations due to many factors not within our control, such as the unpredictability of when customers will order products, the size of customers' orders, the demand for our products, the level of competition or general economic conditions. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>8</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B><U>The Company has strong net income this fiscal year, however, the Company&#146;s prior history of losses could require the need for additional, financings and related problems if net income doesn&#146;t continue.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company had positive net income this fiscal year: $585,948 FY2014 and net loss of ($58,639) in FY2013. &nbsp;The Company may require additional funding to meet its long-term business objectives, if the Company isn&#146;t able to continue the current trend of positive operating income. &nbsp;Capital will be needed to expand manufacturing capacity and marketing of the Company&#146;s products. &nbsp;The Company may not be able to obtain additional financing on reasonable terms, or at all. &nbsp;If equity financing is required, then such financings could result in significant dilution to existing shareholders. &nbsp;If the Company is unable to obtain sufficient financing, the Company might have to dramatically slow marketing efforts and/or lose control of its products. &nbsp;The Company has historically obtained the preponderance of its financing through the issuance of equity. &nbsp;There is a limit of 100,000,000 authorized common shares. &nbsp;The Company has no current plans to obtain financing through means other than equity financing and/or loans. &nbsp;The potential need for external financings could result in losses of investment value.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company&#146;s need for additional financing to expand production and conduct marketing efforts could lead to the Company&#146;s inability to continue generating material sales revenue.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company develops, manufactures, and markets proprietary fire resistant building materials designed to help protect people and property from the destruction of fire. Additional amounts of financing may be required to facilitate corporate operational growth and to expand marketing efforts on a short-term basis. &nbsp;Conventional bank financing was originally established at a local bank for up to $1,000,000 in the form of a revolving line of credit. In July 2008, the terms of the existing revolving bank facility of $1,000,000 were modified to be comprised of a $500,000 capital loan being amortized by the bank over a 10-year period and which is secured by building, property and equipment and a $500,000 credit facility as an operating line of credit at 7.5%. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August 2010, the line of credit was amended to include a reduced limit of $250,000, and was extended until September 1, 2011 at a reduced interest rate of 6.75%. &nbsp;In December 2011, Barrier negotiated a term bank loan facility in the amount of $450,000 bearing interest at 6.25% and collateralized by a security interest in inventory, accounts receivable, equipment and all intangibles of the Company as well as an assignment of the building lease. The facility is being amortized over 4 years with fixed monthly blended payments of principal and interest totaling $6,800 with a balloon payment due on January 1, 2016. &nbsp;At June 30, 2014, the capital loan balance was $312,110. &nbsp;By a promissory note agreement dated June 13, 2014 the Company has arranged for credit facilities with Farmers State Bank of Watkins which allows the Company to be advanced up to $200,000 under the terms of the promissory note agreement. Advances will bear interest at 6.25% per annum and will be repayable in installments of accrued interest beginning June 13, 2014 with the entire unpaid Principal and interest to be repaid on June 13, 2015. &nbsp;The balance at June 30, 2014 was $0.00. &nbsp;Advances are collateralized by a security interest on inventory, accounts receivable, equipment and all intangibles of the Company as well as an assignment of the building lease.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company competes with other building materials companies that have similar operations, and many such competitor companies have operations and financial resources and industry experience far greater than those of the Company.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Even if the Company maintains a successful marketing program, the Company will still be subject to competition from much larger and financially stronger competitors and such competition may materially adversely affect the Company&#146;s financial performance. &nbsp;Also, the Company&#146;s need to acquire inventory will require additional financial resources.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><B>Risks Relating to Management and Specific Operations</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company&#146;s Articles/By-Laws contain provisions indemnifying its officers and directors against all costs, charges and expenses incurred by them.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s Articles/By-Laws contain provisions that state, subject to applicable law, the Company shall indemnify every director or officer of the Company, subject to the limitations of the British Columbia Corporations Act, against all losses or liabilities that the Company&#146;s director or officer may sustain or incur in the execution of their duties. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s Articles/By-Laws further state that no director of officer shall be liable for any loss, damage or misfortune that may happen to, or be incurred by the Company in the execution of their duties if they acted honestly and in good faith with a view to the best interests of the Company. &nbsp;Such limitations on liability may reduce the likelihood of litigation against the Company&#146;s officers and directors and may discourage or deter its shareholders from suing the Company&#146;s officers and directors based upon breaches of their duties to the Company, though such an action, if successful, might otherwise benefit the Company and its shareholders.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>9</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B><U>Key management employees may fail to properly carry out their duties or may leave which could negatively impact corporate operations and/or stock pricing.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>While developing, manufacturing, and marketing proprietary fire resistant building materials designed to help protect people and property from the destruction of fire, the nature of the Company&#146;s business, its ability to develop a successful sales force, and to develop a competitive edge in the marketplace, depends, in large part, on its ability to attract and maintain qualified key management personnel. &nbsp;Competition for such personnel is intense and the Company may not be able to attract and retain such personnel. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s growth will depend on the efforts of its Directors (David Corcoran, Michael Huddy, and Victor Yates) and its Senior Management. &nbsp;President/CEO/Director, Michael Huddy, and CFO, Melissa McElwee, work for the Company on a full-time basis. &nbsp;The Corporate Secretary, Lindsey Nauen works for the Company on a part-time basis. &nbsp;The Company carries no key-man insurance and there are no written agreements with them.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-19.2px" align=center><B>Risks Relating to the Company&#146;s Common Stock</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Principal stockholders, officers and directors have substantial control regarding stock ownership; this concentration could lead to conflicts of interest and difficulties in the &#147;public&#148; investors effecting corporate changes, and could adversely affect the Company&#146;s stock prices.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s Senior Management, Directors and greater-than-five-percent stockholders (and their affiliates), acting together, hold approximately 28% of the shares of the Company, on a diluted basis, and have the ability to control substantially all matters submitted to the Company&#146;s stockholders for approval (including the election and removal of directors and any merger, consolidation or sale of all or substantially all of the Company&#146;s assets) and to control the Company&#146;s management and affairs. &nbsp;Accordingly, this concentration of ownership may have the effect of delaying, deferring or preventing a change in control of the Company, impeding a merger, consolidation, takeover or other business combination involving the Company or discouraging a potential acquirer from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain control of the Company, which in turn could materially adversely affect the market price of the Company&#146;s stock.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Employee/Director/Consultant stock options could lead to greater concentration of stock ownership among insiders and could lead to dilution of stock ownership which could lead to depressed stock prices.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Because the success of the Company is highly dependent upon its respective employees, the Company has granted to some or all of its key employees, Directors and consultants options to purchase common shares as non-cash incentives. &nbsp;To the extent that significant numbers of such options may be granted and exercised, the interests of the other stockholders of the Company may be diluted causing possible loss of investment value.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>The Company has never declared or paid cash dividends on its common shares and does not anticipate doing so in the foreseeable future.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>There can be no assurance that the Company&#146;s Board of Directors will ever declare cash dividends, which action is exclusively within its discretion. &nbsp;Investors cannot expect to receive a dividend on the Company&#146;s common shares in the foreseeable future, if at all.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Low stock market prices and volume volatility for the Company&#146;s common shares create a risk that investors might not be able to effect purchases/sales at prices that accurately reflect corporate value.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The market for the common shares of the Company on the OTC Bulletin Board in the United States may be highly volatile for reasons both related to the performance of the Company or events pertaining to the industry (i.e., price fluctuation/technological change/new competitor) as well as factors unrelated to the Company or its industry. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s common shares can be expected to be subject to volatility in both price and volume arising from market expectations. &nbsp;Stockholders of the Company may be unable to sell significant quantities of common shares in the public trading markets without a significant reduction in the price of the common shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Broker-Dealers may be discouraged from effecting transactions in the Company&#146;s common shares because they are subject to the penny stock rules.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Rules 15g-1 through 15g-9 promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, impose sales practice and disclosure requirements on NASD broker-dealers who make a market in &#147;penny stock&#148;. &nbsp;A penny stock generally includes any non-NASDAQ equity security that has a market price of less than $5.00 per share. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s shares are quoted on the OTC Bulletin Board in the United States and the TSX Venture Exchange in Canada. &nbsp;The additional sales practice and disclosure requirements imposed upon broker-dealers may discourage broker-dealers from effecting transactions in the Company&#146;s shares, which could severely limit the market liquidity of the shares and impede the sale of the Company&#146;s shares in the secondary market.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>10</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Under the penny stock regulations, a broker-dealer selling penny stock to anyone other than an established customer or &#147;accredited investor&#148; (generally, an individual with net worth in excess of $1,000,000 or an annual income exceeding $200,000, or $300,000 together with his or her spouse) must make a special suitability determination for the purchaser and must receive the purchaser's written consent to the transaction prior to sale, unless the broker-dealer or the transaction is otherwise exempt.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>In addition, the penny stock regulations require the broker-dealer to deliver, prior to any transaction involving a penny stock, a disclosure schedule prepared by the US SEC relating to the penny stock market, unless the broker-dealer or the transaction is otherwise exempt. &nbsp;A broker-dealer is also required to disclose commissions payable to the broker-dealer and the registered representative and current quotations for the securities. &nbsp;Finally, a broker-dealer is required to send monthly statements disclosing recent price information with respect to the penny stock held in a customer's account and information with respect to the limited market in penny stocks.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367868998"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 1B. &nbsp;UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">None</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367868999"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 2. &nbsp;DESCRIPTION OF PROPERTY</U></B> &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s operating and manufacturing facilities, along with executive offices, are located in leased premises at 510 Fourth Street North, Watkins, Minnesota. &nbsp;The Company entered into a 20-year &#147;capital lease&#148; beginning 6/1/1995. &nbsp;The lease allows the Company to purchase the facility for a small &#147;transfer fee&#148; once the 20-year lease is up and the industrial development bonds the City of Watkins issued to fund the project are paid in full.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s manufacturing complex consists of two manufacturing lines housed in the main building. &nbsp;A 2,500 square-foot office is located in the front of this building. &nbsp;To the immediate east of the main drive, two storage buildings (90&#146; x 60&#146; and 106&#146; x 60&#146;) allow for short-term storage of untreated sheathing.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The earlier of the two production lines, our spray technology line, is housed nearest the offices and occupies approximately 22,000 sq. ft. of space. &nbsp;This line is primarily used for panels larger than 4&#146; x 8&#146; or for production not suited for the highly automated standard production line, including plywood. &nbsp;The mix for this line is produced in batches and fed through a reciprocating spray apparatus on to the panels. &nbsp;The fiberglass is supplied as roving and automatically chopped as it is applied to the panels. &nbsp;An infra-red oven supplies the energy to accelerate the cure of the coating; space is provided for the panels to be stacked. &nbsp;Specialty panels can be stacked in custom designed racks if required. The designed capacity from this line is 8MM board feet per shift. &nbsp;We are currently running two shifts on this line.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The newer of the two lines, our automated line, is housed in the extension added to the main building in 2004. &nbsp;This portion of the building is 15,000 sq. feet and houses a completely separate line. &nbsp;This line runs at 20 feet per minute and is capable of producing over 20MM board feet per shift annually when running at 100% efficiency. &nbsp;We currently need to operate this line one shift only, but could quickly increase our capacity to meet market demand by adding shift(s). &nbsp;Automation efficiencies on this line cover: unstacking and restacking of panels; use of automated Pyrotite coating equipment, a computer controlled mixing area; automatic panel weight information fed back continuously to the operators; and a custom panel curing system. &nbsp;This line produces panels of much higher, consistent quality than the older line, at a much more marketable cost point.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Future growth plans may include plants modeled after this new line, placed strategically near markets of prime opportunity; built either by Barrier or with licensed partners.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Regardless of which line is used, the production process for the Pyrotite&#174; technology contains no hazardous or controlled substances that could raise environmental concerns. &nbsp;&nbsp;The majority of the materials used in the production of Pyrotite&#174; are naturally occurring and are therefore accepted at local land-fills. &nbsp;Use and handling instructions for the Company&#146;s finished products are no more stringent than those required for handling other natural wood based building products.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869000"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 3. &nbsp;LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Directors and the management of the Company know of no other material, active or pending, legal proceedings against them; nor is the Company involved as a plaintiff in any material proceeding or pending litigation.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Directors and the management of the Company know of no active or pending proceedings against anyone that might materially adversely affect an interest of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869001"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 4. &nbsp;MINE SAFETY DISCLOSURES</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">Not applicable</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>11</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869002"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-size:12pt" align=center><B>PART II</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869003"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 5. &nbsp;MARKET FOR COMMON EQUITY AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Market Information</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company's common shares began trading on the TSX Venture Exchange (formerly the Canadian Venture Exchange) in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, under its former name Barrier Technology Inc. in September 1986. &nbsp;The current stock symbol is &#147;IBH.V&#148;. &nbsp;The CUSIP number is #458968-10-4.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company&#146;s common shares began trading on the OTC Bulletin Board in August 2002. &nbsp;The current stock symbol is IBTGF.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Holders</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company's common shares are issued in registered form and the following information is taken from the records of Computershare (located in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada), the registrar and transfer agent for the common shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>On 10/28/2013, the Company&#146;s shareholders&#146; list showed 44,454,926 common shares outstanding and 137 registered shareholders with: 6,414,169 shares owned by 41 registered shareholders/depositories resident in Canada, 14% of the total; 38,040,657 shares owned by 95 registered shareholders/depositories resident in the United States; and 100 shares owned by one shareholder in one other country.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>12</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Based on this research and other research into the indirect holdings of other financial institutions, the Company believes that it has approximately 6000 beneficial owners of its common shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Dividends</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company has not declared any dividends since incorporation and does not anticipate that it will do so in the foreseeable future. &nbsp;The present policy of the Company is to retain future earnings for use in its operations and expansion of its business. &nbsp;There are no restrictions that limit the ability of the Company to pay dividends on common equity or that are likely to do so in the future.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Use of Proceeds From Sales of Securities is for working capital</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Recent Sales of Unregistered Securities</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company relied on the exemptions from registration under Regulation S for the following private placements of securities to only Canadian residents:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:19.2px">Fiscal 2011: 40,000 units at US$0.09 per unit = US$3,600</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:19.2px">Fiscal 2012: None</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:19.2px">Fiscal 2013: None</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:19.2px">Fiscal 2014: 100,000 units at US$0.097 per unit = US$9,700</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=213.533><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=84.467><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=73.133><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=76.2><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=83.6><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=83.2><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>

<P style="margin:0px" align=center>13</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869005"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 7. &nbsp;MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The SEC defines critical accounting policies as those that are, in management's view, important to the portrayal of the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations and require management's judgment. &nbsp;The discussion and analysis of the financial condition and results of operations is based on the audited consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (&quot;U.S. GAAP&quot;). &nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses. &nbsp;Management bases its estimates on experience and on various assumptions that it believes are reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. &nbsp;Actual results may differ from those estimates. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s critical accounting policies include:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><U>Revenue Recognition</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) Staff Accounting Bulletin 104, &#147;Revenue Recognition&#148;, which requires that: (i) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (ii) delivery has occurred, (iii) the sales price is fixed and determinable, and (iv) collectibility is reasonably assured. The Company recognizes revenue when the building supplies have been shipped or title has been released for customer arranged freight.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><U>Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company reviews the recoverability of its long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. &nbsp;The estimated future cash flows are based upon, among other things, assumptions about future operating performance, and may differ from actual cash flows. &nbsp;Long-lived assets evaluated for impairment are grouped with other assets to the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other groups of assets and liabilities. &nbsp;If the sum of the projected undiscounted cash flows (excluding interest) is less than the carrying value of the assets, the assets will be written down to the estimated fair value in the period in which the determination is made.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><U>Stock-based Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company accounts for all stock-based payments and awards under the fair value based method.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Stock-based payments to non-employees are measured at the fair value of the consideration received, or the fair value of the equity instruments issued, or liabilities incurred, whichever is more reliably measurable. &nbsp;The fair value of stock-based payments to non-employees is periodically re-measured until the counterparty performance is complete, and any change therein is recognized over the vesting period of the award and in the same manner as if the Company had paid cash instead of paying with or using equity based instruments. &nbsp;The cost of the stock-based payments to non-employees that is fully vested and non-forfeitable as at the grant date is measured and recognized at that date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company accounts for the granting of share purchase options to employees using the fair value method whereby all awards to employees will be recorded at fair value on the date of the grant. &nbsp;The fair value of all share purchase options are expensed over their vesting period with a corresponding increase to additional capital surplus. &nbsp;Upon exercise of share purchase options, the consideration paid by the option holder, together with the amount previously recognized in additional paid-in capital is recorded as an increase to share capital.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The Company uses the binomial option pricing model to determine the fair value of all stock based awards classified as liabilities and the Black-Scholes option pricing model to calculate the fair value of share purchase options. &nbsp;Option pricing models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, including the expected price volatility. &nbsp;Changes in these assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><B><U>Equity Financing Timeline</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2011: &nbsp;40,000 units at US$0.09 per unit = US$3,600</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2012: &nbsp;None</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2013: &nbsp;None</P>
<P style="margin:0px">Fiscal 2014: &nbsp;100,000 units at US$0.097 per unit = US$9,700</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>14</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><B><U>Fiscal 2014 Ended 6/30/2014</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. (Barrier) manufactures and sells fire-rated building materials. Barrier&#146;s primary business is in the United States but through the development of distribution partnerships and manufacturing technology license agreements is successfully endeavoring to enter building products markets in Australia, Europe, and South America. Barrier possesses a proprietary fire resistive material technology (Pyrotite&#174;) and a patented manufacturing process that when applied to building materials their respective fire resistant properties are significantly enhanced. &nbsp;Many of the top multifamily and wood frame commercial builders in the United States utilize Barrier&#146;s fire-rated structural panels in areas where the building code requires the use of a fire-rated building panel.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier currently manufactures a private label fire rated sheathing product under contract for both LP<SUP>&#174; </SUP>Building Products, Inc. (LP) and MuleHide Products, Inc. (MuleHide). &nbsp;LP introduced a fire rated OSB trademarked LP<SUP>&#174;</SUP> Flameblock<SUP>&#174;</SUP> Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing (LP FlameBlock) in 2010 and MuleHide has been selling MuleHide FR Deck Panel (FR Deck Panel) to commercial modular building manufacturers since 2004.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s financial statements are filed with both the SEC (USA) and SEDAR (Canada) and are disclosed in US dollars utilizing US generally accepted accounting principles. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s filings with the SEC consist of quarterly reviews financial statements on Form 10-Q and annual audited financial statements on Form 10-K. &nbsp;Barrier continues to file the above financial statements with SEDAR in Canada.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Sales</U> </B>revenue reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2014 was up 36% to $8,154,389 in comparison to $5,994,994 generated in the same fiscal period in 2013. Total sales volume, as measured by surface volume of product shipped, was 19,750,792 sq ft; an all time high for Barrier for the third year in a row. &nbsp;This is a 49% increase from the 13,243,741 sq. ft. shipped during the previous year. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Shipments into the Residential Roof Deck, Wall Assembly, and Structural Insulated Panel Market Sectors (LP FlameBlock) during the fiscal year increased 52% over shipments in fiscal 2013. &nbsp;Sales into the Commercial Modular Market (FR Deck Panel) increased 40% in comparison to the previous year. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier and LP conduct business guided by a Supply Agreement that had a term ending on December 31, 2013. &nbsp;The Agreement contains a provision to extend the term annually, upon mutual agreement of both parties. &nbsp;As 2013 came to a close, it was clear that further discussions were warranted to determine how best to strategize future production capacity expansion plans in the US while protecting LP Corporation and Barrier&#146;s respective business interests.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>While Supply Agreement modifications are being discussed, relative to the inherent changes required for future possible expansion, Barrier and LP have agreed to execute short term (30 &#150; 90 day) extensions of the existing Agreement, as needed, to enable purposeful discussions to continue long enough to insure both parties interests have been discussed and accommodated as best possible.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The relationship with LP has contributed to an increase in sales volume to record levels and Barrier anticipates that sales will continue to grow substantially through the sustained efforts of LP&#146;s sales and marketing team. &nbsp;Reported sales revenue for LP products, include only the charges for treatment services, not the underlying OSB substrate or outbound freight as LP supplies its own OSB substrate and contracts for its own outgoing freight. &nbsp;The &#147;pass through&#148; of the OSB substrate and freight serves to lower reported &#147;top line&#148; sales revenue, but not gross profits since margins on substrate and freight have historically been restricted to handling costs only to help keep prices competitive. &nbsp;For the Commercial Modular market, Barrier purchases OSB from local distributors and invoices the cost of the substrate and outgoing freight to the customer, therefore the cost of the substrate and freight is included in revenue for Commercial Modular shipments.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Gross profit</U></B> for the fiscal period was $1,566,493 vs. $709,810 in the previous year. The gross margin, as a percentage of sales revenue, increased to 19% in the current fiscal year from 12% in the prior year. &nbsp;In the near term, gross margins are anticipated to remain relatively flat or perhaps to improve slightly based on continued gains in production efficiency. Capacity limitations at the current manufacturing facility in Watkins Minnesota, however, are being approached and further non-marginal improvement in scale efficiency will be delayed until additional production capacity is added. The development of additional manufacturing capability is anticipated by late 2015. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Cost of sales</U> </B>increased to $6,587,896 from $5,285,184 in Fiscal 2014. &nbsp;The increase is attributable to the increase in volume produced. &nbsp;Barrier created significant gains in manufacturing efficiency as measured by the average cost per square foot of production which decreased from $0.40 to $0.33 during the fiscal reporting period.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>15</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Substrate cost and materials/labor were the major expenses in this category. &nbsp;Substrate accounted for $1,529,837 for the fiscal year versus $1,558,479 in the same period last year. Materials and labor accounted for an additional $3,670,094 in the twelve month period in 2014 versus $2,662,060 in 2013.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Depreciation on plant and equipment is included in cost of sales category. Depreciation, which has non-cash impact on Barrier&#146;s actual cash flow, increased slightly year-to-date from $303,914 in 2013 to $316,862. &nbsp;The expense reflects scheduled depreciation of the newer manufacturing line equipment and building expansion. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Administrative expenses</U></B> for Fiscal 2014 increased to $870,930 from $710,294 in the prior year. &nbsp;The administrative costs per sq. ft. were $0.04 for the fiscal year which was an improvement from $0.05 reported in Fiscal 2013. The positive impact of increased sales volume reducing administrative cost per square foot shipped was captured during this fiscal reporting period. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Accounting and Audit Fees</U></B> decreased from $91,745 to $80,220. &nbsp;A significant portion of the cost for accounting services is involved with the year-end and audited review and publishing of Barrier&#146;s annual financials. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Insurance costs</U></B> have increased from $65,138 to $80,456. &nbsp;The difference is due to annually adjusted premiums based on larger sales volume. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Legal fees</U></B> increased significantly from $36,985 in Fiscal 2013 to $74,712 in Fiscal 2014. &nbsp;Legal fees were expended on activities in support of developing strategic partners and technology licensees, the year-end Annual General Meeting, as well as in monitoring and protecting Pyrotite&#174; patents and trademarks.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier has two US patents, a patent in Australia, and a patent in Canada. These patents protect the manufacturing and process technology utilized in the production of fire-rated sheathing products utilizing Pyrotite&#174;. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Sales, marketing, and investor relations</U></B> expenses decreased from $34,151 to $23,067 for the year. During the year, there were sales trips directly related to the expansion of product markets.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s cost for sales and marketing will continue to remain at current levels relative to sales volume as our partners, LP and MuleHide Products, perform the majority of those functions themselves. Barrier remains active in a support role by providing necessary technical sales support but most of the day to day market and sales development activities are already being performed by the capable sales and marketing staffs of LP and MuleHide Products resulting in improved sales but also lower costs for Barrier.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Wages and management fees</U></B> increased to $497,169 from $388,649. &nbsp;The major increase in the fee is attributed to the non-cash valuation of options granted during the period. &nbsp;In addition, Barrier added a part-time administration team member to assist with the growing sales volumes.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Operating Income</U> </B>of $695,563 is being reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2014, whereas in the same period in 2013, a net loss of ($484) was reported.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The significant improvement in operating income is a result of increased sales volumes and focus on manufacturing efficiency. It is Barrier&#146;s fundamental belief that sustained increased sales volume coupled with an intense focus on manufacturing efficiency is the best pathway to long-term profitability. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Other items </U></B>include income and costs not directly related to business operations. &nbsp;Other income items reported during the fiscal year herein includes a foreign exchange loss of $611 and interest/other income of $350. &nbsp;To compare, for the same reporting period last year there was a foreign exchange gain of $8,116 and interest/other income of $792. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Interest on Long Term Debt has decreased from $67,063 to $61,292 for the 12-month reporting period as a result of larger principal payments as long term debt ages.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Net Income.</U> &nbsp;</B>Net income of $585,948 is being reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2014, whereas in the same period in 2013, a net loss of $58,639 was reported. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier remains focused on cutting costs and improving efficiencies wherever it can. &nbsp;This includes operating the manufacturing line with maximum efficiency. Keeping a vigilant handle on costs will help keep operational costs as low as possible and enable financial improvements to continue and at lower volumes than previously possible.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>16</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>New product and market development</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier continues to provide support to LP for new product and market development in activity directed specifically toward applications in geographic areas where wildfires are prevalent and where building code development is becoming more restrictive with respect to designing for improved fire resistance. Focus has continued on developing products engineered to meet requirements established for Wildland/Urban Interface (WUI) zones. WUI zones are primarily located in the western US, and are areas where special building codes have been developed to help save homes if a brush fire should occur. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Enhanced focus has been made over this past year on developing products used in multifamily residential projects since the multifamily market is strong and is expected to stay vibrant over the next few years. In particular, Barrier and LP&#146;s introduction of a UL certified 2-hr exterior load bearing wall designed for use in wood-frame buildings of Type III construction is being well received by architects, building code professionals and builders alike. As more architects and specifying engineers become aware of this new design Barrier and LP are confident that considerable sales will result for these projects.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Most recently, Barrier and LP have begun exploring opportunities related to emerging code requirements for Engineered Wood Products (EWP) such as I-Joist and RimBoard. &nbsp;I-Joist and Rimboard produced using oriented strand board (OSB) technology are widely used in the building industry but have only recently been put under intense scrutiny for structural performance in a fire. &nbsp;Barrier and LP believe there is significant opportunity in developing EWP products that are rated for performance in a fire situation.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Some preliminary fire tests have already been conducted with positive results. &nbsp;Pyrotite technology seems to provide EWP with sufficient improvement in fire resistance and structural integrity. &nbsp;Barrier and LP&#146;s EWP Division will be actively researching these exciting opportunities in the ensuing fiscal year and will endeavor to develop products that will meet code requirements being developed by the International Code Council (ICC). </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center>17</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Global licensing opportunities</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier continues to explore manufacturing and distribution opportunities for Pyrotite<SUP>&#174;</SUP> technology in geographies outside of the US. &nbsp;During the fiscal year, Barrier announced a licensing agreement for the manufacture and distribution of Pyrotite<SUP>&#174;</SUP> products in the European Union and Russia. &nbsp;Kronospan, a world-wide leader in OSB manufacturing, has officially added &#147;OSB Pyrotite ECO&#148; (a fire-resistant OSB panel) to their family of products. &nbsp;Barrier provided technical assistance in the design of their first manufacturing line, the transfer of production process technology, and material acquisition criteria. &nbsp;The manufacturing line is now fully operational. &nbsp;The license agreement provides for a payment made quarterly to Barrier by the Licensee of a royalty based on the volume of product produced. A minimum annual royalty fee was established along with an &#147;up-front&#148; license fee which was paid pursuant to the execution of the license agreement earlier in the year. &nbsp;The agreement contemplates the Licensee developing additional production facilities over the term of the license and making additional royalty payments to Barrier based on these plants production. &nbsp;The license agreement follows standard licensing protocol, which allows for the audit of manufacturing process and financial revenue information. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>The selection of Pyrotite<SUP>&#174; </SUP>technology by the licensor after extensive research and testing of several other fire-resistant technologies adds additional credibility to our Pyrotite<SUP>&#174; </SUP>technology and could lead to potential interest in other geographies.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Financial position &amp; financings</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier ended the fiscal year with a working capital surplus (current assets less current liabilities) of $585,647. &nbsp;Operating cash flow was $784,836 in comparison to $314,821 for the year ended June 30, 2013.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Barrier has a short term revolving line of credit ($200,000) at the local Farmers State Bank of Watkins, in Watkins, Minnesota. &nbsp;As of June 30, 2014 the balance owing on the revolving line of credit was $0 leaving an additional $200,000 available for use. &nbsp;In addition, two convertible debentures in the amount of $150,000 each were established in December 2011. &nbsp;To date, $240,000 has been drawn on these debentures with an additional $60,000 available for cash flow if needed.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Investing activities resulted in net cash outflow of $134,124 in the current period in comparison to a net cash outflow of $155,121 in the prior year. &nbsp;The cash outflow was the result of the acquisition of plant and equipment capital improvements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>Financing activities resulted in net cash outflow of $121,364 in the current year compared to a net cash inflow of $81,645 for last year. &nbsp;The cash outflow resulted from the repayments on long-term debt and obligations under capital lease. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>There is no assurance that Barrier will operate profitably or will generate positive cash flow in the future. In addition, Barrier&#146;s operating results in the future may be subject to significant fluctuations due to many factors not within our control, such as the unpredictability of when customers will order products, the size of customers' orders, the demand for our products, the level of competition or general economic conditions. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Current and Future Financing Needs</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>At June 30, 2014, the current cash and cash equivalents totaled $708,926; there was $200,000 in available funds to draw on the revolving credit facility, and an additional $60,000 available from the convertible debentures. &nbsp;Over the next twelve months, the Company anticipates that the operation of business will produce an average monthly operating cash flow of $75,000 for a total of $900,000 for the 2014 fiscal year. &nbsp;In addition, over the next 12 months, the Company is required to make payments totaling $162,773 in respect of its long-term and capital lease obligations and $666,932 in respect of accounts payable outstanding as at June 30, 2014. &nbsp;Based on the foregoing, management believes there will be sufficient cash to maintain operations for the next 12 months. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><B><U>Related Party Transactions</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify>During the year ended June 30, 2012, the Company approved the issuance of two convertible debentures to a director and a company controlled by a director in the amount of $300,000. &nbsp;The debentures are being issued in tranches from $10,000 - $50,000 and as at June 30, 2014 the Company had received $240,000 (2013: &nbsp;$240,000) in respect of these debentures. &nbsp;The debentures bear interest at 12% per annum, payable quarterly, and are collateralized by a third charge over the Company&#146;s plant and equipment as well as a charge against the Company&#146;s patents. &nbsp;At any time, the notes are convertible into units of the Company at a price of $0.10 per unit. &nbsp;Each unit will consist of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the holder the right to purchase one additional share for $0.10 for a period of two years from the conversion date. &nbsp;During the year ended June 30, 2014, the Company incurred interest charges of $28,800 (2013: &nbsp;$27,158) on these convertible debentures. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
